Giveth me a break, Walter: superbly written commentary, poetic well beyond my meager gifts, but so narrow. Surely you remember the left's assaults on Nixon and Reagan, and the monumental avalanche of derision heaped upon Dubya (that continues to this day, largely to provide thin skirts behind which the president is invited to hide).

Barack Obama is a big boy, grabbed for the brass ring, secured it and is hanging on for dear life. But anyone who thinks that ride ever is joyous in the teeth of committed ideological resistance, that ALL presidents face, is whistling a purer Dixie than ever was heard even in your lovely city of Charleston.

My memories of "desultory, disgraceful remarks" of those who use such means as their weapons is less convenient than yours.

Richard:  You're not as objective as you think. What other president had a member of Congress shout "You lie!" during a speech? Had his citizenship questioned and the proof of citizenship scoffed at when it was shown? Had people seriously want to see his grades from high school and college? Uh-uh. The level of vitriol *is* different, and harsher.

This post and the mention of Remnick's brings to mind an old truism from Haight-Ashbury when mirrors were held up for the tour buses--what we see is our own vision--we are the geeks, not those that we see.

"Detachment, insularity, antithetical to politics?" We witnessed the most severe daily pounding by the blunt force of words of any President in our history--wryly ignored by those paid to be blind to all but their own view, offered as canons of insight.

Rather than take the short or long list of public assaults endured, look for a moment at the reactions of the witnesses: commenters (here!) confessed physical symptoms, tension, anxiety, stomach distress in varying degrees, head pains, labored breathing, weaknesses, changed sensory perceptions; add psychological changes: anger, aversions to reading or listening to desultory, disgraceful remarks that shamed the President, the Office, and the country by every conceivable insult and symbol--all, of course, in jest! Vastly without foundation, but endlessly looped.

The only remarkable spot of public joy was the quiet speech, sharing he knew how others spoke, and how he found, despite temptations and provocations, what the I Ching calls the posture of jade (soft within, hard without) to stand before his enemies and not engage in order to preserve the country no one said he loved and that others were and still are willing to tear apart.

Huey Long is gone. Jesse ran. It's Barack turn. And he had nowhere to hide.

It's more than the typical generational divide. It's a new archetype, a shift at the depth in Jungian philosophy/psychology; the old patterns of heroes and villains, the folly of young, and yes, the wisdom of age, did not hold and went away.

It is not the screen experience; the hearts and souls of those whose fingers strike the keys have become outliers.

Since its beginnings, America has had a fascination with the outlier, the swashbuckling rogues who reject the odds to further self-shouldered missions.

They were transformed not by duty but by their inner furies. They were propelled into a darkness beyond dark money. Outliers are self-invented—or self assembled. For them internet politics serves as a stage; a way to shine on their own terms. They are self-absorbed. They bear little allegiance to tradition, perform well in brief spurts, use the status quo for comfort but trample on the edges of the social order, and often leverage alienation into fame.

And some take death to early, as a last lament.

This is true.

After trying to help with a few different fundraising strategies for my kids school, including straight requests for donations, I settled on running the auction every year. It works. I've pretty much got the hang of it all now -- local businesses donate for advertising purposes, parents bid to be conspicuous and snag a deal, people get a thrill out of winning stuff, people like to feel like they are being charitable while getting something in return, and adults like to get together with other adults over dinner and wine. Every year it brings in triple what we're able to collect by just asking for straight donations from parents.

Personally, I just donate. I help put on the event, but I don't bid unless I'm trying to drive up the winning bid. Personally, I find it more sensible to attend budget meetings to get some of this funding from where it's *supposed* to come from. But a single flyer for the auction brings in 100 families, and a flyer for the budget meeting brings in the same 5 families again and again… If I'm going to spin my wheels, I'd rather see it amount to something.

On Paul Krugman's Monday post, I noted: "Out of the corner of our eye, we see countries creating wealth and ending poverty, growing a middle class. Brasil, India, China, Ghana, others. Their progress is not perfect, but their gains are real. We ignore them. Speak only of their shortcomings, ignore their advance."

Further back, Sept. 7, 2011: "The past 3 presidential elections have seen Brasil elect 2 socialists as President, a militant Union member, a former guerrilla who was tortured and jailed. Both socialist Presidents have shown skillful ability at managing Brasil’s political economy and politics, and none of the worst fears of their foes are in evidence. To the contrary, Brasil entered one of its greatest periods of forward progress, in world markets and local communities. The notion of a fatherland, motherland, or homeland seemed a slightly racist notion heard most often in authoritarian states, or as a remnant of a worst past when still used in democratic states.

I know I am over-idealizing the past, but I am very saddened by how far fear has driven us even further from these ideals.
